description.summary: The most dangerous water horse variant in Scottish Highland folklore. Inhabits sea lochs and ocean, appears as a beautiful horse, drags victims to water, drowns and devours them completely except for the liver which floats to the surface.
description.full: The each-uisge (pronounced 'ech-ooshkya') is considered the most malevolent and dangerous of the Scottish water horses. Unlike its cousin the kelpie which inhabits freshwater rivers and lochs, the each-uisge dwells in the sea and sea lochs of the Scottish Highlands. It appears as a beautiful horse, often white or grey, and like the kelpie possesses adhesive skin that traps anyone who touches it. Once a victim is stuck, the each-uisge plunges into the water and drowns them. Most horrifically, the each-uisge then devours its victim entirely, with only the liver floating to the surface - a grisly calling card. The creature can also shapeshift into human form (a handsome man) or sometimes into a huge bird. In human form, the each-uisge can be detected by water weeds in their hair and webbed fingers. The each-uisge is distinguished from the kelpie primarily by habitat (sea vs. freshwater) and its more extreme lethality. In Highland folklore, it represents the ultimate danger of the sea and serves as a potent warning against approaching strange horses near coastal waters.

range.description: Scottish Highlands, particularly western coast and islands. Inhabits sea lochs, bays, and coastal waters. Irish variant (aughisky) found in Ireland.

hotspots.name: Sea lochs of Western Highlands
hotspots.notes: Numerous sea lochs with each-uisge tales

first_recorded.source: Scottish Highland oral traditions, written records from 17th century

temporal.seasonal_patterns: Year-round danger, though stories often set in summer

origins.cultural_roots: Ancient Scottish Highland water spirit folklore. Reflects the deadly danger of sea lochs and coastal waters. More feared than the freshwater kelpie due to association with the unpredictable ocean.
origins.earliest_accounts: Oral traditions ancient; documented in written Highland folklore from 1600s onward.
origins.folklore_connections: Part of broader Celtic water horse tradition. Related to Irish aughisky. Shares characteristics with kelpie but considered more dangerous. Distinguished by saltwater habitat and complete consumption of victims.

history.modern_era: Each-uisge remains important in Highland folklore, though less well-known than the kelpie outside Scotland. Represents the ultimate danger of the sea in Highland tradition.

Human form seduction tales near sea lochs
folklore.beliefs: Each-uisge considered most dangerous of water horses. Avoided sea lochs and coastal horses. Liver floating to surface as sign of each-uisge predation. Some believed iron or rowan provided limited protection.

indigenous.significance: Central to Highland sea safety folklore. Reflected real dangers of sea lochs - deep water, strong currents, tidal effects, cold temperatures. More feared than kelpie due to ocean association and complete consumption of victims.
indigenous.sensitivity_note: Each-uisge folklore is traditional Highland Scottish cultural heritage.
indigenous.respect_guidelines: Recognize each-uisge tales as meaningful cultural heritage with origins in maritime safety education and respect for the sea.
